"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the ambient air from a stationary source."
The release must have caused at least one of the following:
	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a))."
Based on the above definition and upon verification with the facility on September 12, 2024, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet this criteria in the past five years (September 2019 - September 2024). 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Fresh Express is a non-responding facility and has an emergency action plan (EAP) in effect. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
1.	To save lives.
2.	To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.	To protect the environment.
4.	To minimize property damage.
The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM / RMP / CalARP regulations.
In the event of an ammonia emergency, the operator of the Fresh Express facility plans to evacuate all employees in the facility and alert the local emergency responders (fire department). The operator of the facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study, conducted on September 12, 2024, including a What-If study and a facility inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Fresh Express facility. Fresh Express's safety committ

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
This Executive Summary contains Fresh Express's administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia-related accidents and reduce potential risks. The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is ammonia. The following topics are addressed in the Executive Summary:
	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
	Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
	Hazard Assessment Summary
	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
	Five Year Accident History
	Emergency Response Program
	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
	Updating
The following Data Elements sections are attached:
	Section 1: Registration Information
	Section 2: Toxics - Worst Case Release
	Section 3: Toxics - Alternative Release
	Section 4: Flammables - Worst Case Release (NOT APPLICABLE)
	Section 5: Flammables - Alternative Release (NOT APPLICABLE)
	Section 6: Five Year Accident History
	Section 7: Prevention Program 3 Component
	Section 8: Prevention Program 2 Component (NOT APPLICABLE)
	Section 9: Emergency Response Component

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Fresh Express is a ready-to-eat salad production company. The facility was constructed in 1999.
Fresh Express is not only committed to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities, but also to offering superior service. Fresh Express Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.
The Fresh Express facility has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the local Fire Department. In the case of an ammonia emergency, it is the policy of Fresh Express to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Fresh Express facility is located at 900 East Blan

co Road, in Salinas, California, which is approximately 1.2 miles west of Highway 101. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban.
When in service, the refrigeration process equipment operates continuously. The Compressors cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation. The Compressors, Suction Accumulators, Emergency Control Box, and Auto Purger are located inside the Engine Room, the Evaporative Condensers and the High Pressure Receivers are located outside, and the Low Pressure Receivers, Air Units, and Water Chillers are located in Processing Zones 1 - 6.
The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Evaporative Condensers (EC-1, EC-2, EC-3, EC-4, EC-5, EC-6, EC-7) to the High Pressure Receivers (HVR-1, HVR-2).
The Suction Accumulators (SA-1, SA-2, SA-3, SA-4) receive high pressure liquid from the High Pressure Receivers. The liquid ammonia travels through a sub-cooling coil inside of the vessel, which reduces the temperature of the liquid. The resulting subcooled liquid is then fed to the Low Pressure Receivers (LPR-1, LPR-2, LPR-3, LPR-4, LPR-5, LPR-6), and to the Compressors (SC-1, SC-2, SC-3, SC-4, SC-5, SC-6, SC-7) for oil cooling. The Suction Accumulators also receive return suction from the Low Pressure Receivers. Liquid present in the return suction drops to the bottom of the vessel where it is boiled off by the coils, and the vapor rises to the top of the vessel and is drawn off by the Compressors.
The Low Pressure Receivers receive subcooled liquid ammonia from the Suction Accumulators. The liquid ammonia is then pumped to Air Units located in Zones 1, 2, 3, and 4, and to Water Chillers in Zones 5 and 6, where it is partially vaporized as heat is removed from the water, product, and cooler/processing rooms. The resulting liquid/vapor is drawn back to the Low Pressure Receivers.
High stage suction is drawn from the Suction Accumulators by the Compressors, where the pressure and temperature of the

vapor is increased. Compressor discharge (high pressure ammonia vapor, or hot gas) is then sent to the Evaporative Condensers, where the vapor condenses into a high pressure liquid and is returned to the High Pressure Receivers to begin the refrigeration cycle again. Some compressor discharge is also sent to the Air Units in Zones 1, 2, 3, and 4, for hot gas defrost purposes. Liquid injection oil cooling is provided by the High Pressure Receivers.
The vessels and compressor oil separators are equipped with pressure relief valves which vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank.
An auto purger (AP-1) is present to remove non-condensables from the system. There is an Emergency Control Box in place as well to help refrigeration operators diffuse high pressure scenarios before pressure relief valves activate.
The maximum intended inventory of ammonia is 60,000 pounds.
The system is monitored 24 hours a day via the control system. When off-site, operators are notified in the event of an alarm and/or system shutdown.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Fresh Express ammonia system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.
The PSM / RMP / CalARP program ensures that all security and safety procedures are addressed. Staff is trained in operation, maintenance and emergency procedures related to the operation of the ammonia system. All pressure vessels in the ammonia system are equipped with relief valves that vent to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank at a certain pressure set point. A preventative maintenance program assures that equipment is maintained and serviced on a regular schedule and that worn, aging, or defective components are replaced as required to maintain equipment in good operating condition. Controls and safety devices are inspected regularly to ensure proper operation.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

9.	Within one month of a change to emergency contact information; a correction must be filed with the Monterey County Health Department, Environmental Health Bureau.

In the event that Fresh Express intends to make a modification to the ammonia system and that modification may result in a significant increase in either, (i) the amount of ammonia handled at the facility; or (ii) the risk of handling the ammonia as compared to the amount of risk identified in the facility's PSM / RMP / CalARP document, then Fresh Express will do the following:
1.	Notify the Monterey County Health Department, Environmental Health Bureau in writing of the intent to modify the facility at least five calendar days before implementing any modifications. As part of the notification process, the Engineering/Maintenance Manager shall consult with the Monterey County Health Department, Environmental Health Bureau to determine the necessary documentation modification requirements. If pre-notification is not possible, Fresh Express will provide a written notice no later than 48 hours following the modification.
2.	Update the necessary documentation within 60 days from the date of the modification.
Note: The CalARP Program Regulation defines a reportable accident [19 CCR 5800.9 (a)] to be the following:
"The owner or operator shall include in the Five Year Accident History all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage."
